{{other people||Victor Griffin (disambiguation){{!}}Victor Griffin}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Victor William Griffin | native_name = Geh-Hu-He Jinka | native_name_lang = [[Quapaw language]] | birth_date = {{Birth year|1873}} | birth_place = [[Indian Territory]], modern day [[Osage County, Oklahoma]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1958|04|10|1873|6|6}} | death_place = [[Quapaw, Oklahoma]] | office = Chief of the Quapaw Tribe, Peyote Roadman | term_start = 1929 | term_end = 1956/7<ref name=blue/> | predecessor = John Quapaw | successor = Robert Whitebird<ref name=blue/> | known_for = last elected Chief of the Quapaw Tribe prior to the creation of the Quapaw Tribal Business Committee | notable_works = facilitated the incorporation of the Native American Church under Oklahoma law | party = | alma_mater = Quapaw Indian School | profession = Interpreter, [[peyote roadman]], chief | spouse = Good Eagle, Sarah Lewis, Minnie Track | residence = [[Quapaw, Oklahoma]] | website = }}
'''Victor Griffin''' (c. 1873–1958) was the [[Tribal chief|elected chief]] of [[Quapaw Tribe of Indians]] and a [[peyote roadman]]<ref name="religion">{{cite book|last1=Stewart|first1=Omer Call|title=Peyote Religion: A History|date=1993|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=978-0-8061-2457-5|pages=110–115, 188|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZesN1ZJNMQYC&lpg=PA115&dq=Victor%20Griffin&pg=PA188#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> from [[Quapaw, Oklahoma]]. He conferred with every U.S. president during his term as chief.
Griffin also served as an interpreter and also was an important figure among the practitioners of the Big Moon variant of the [[Native American Church]], and played a significant role in the spreading and continuing this religion among multiple tribes.<ref name=religion/><ref name=baird>{{Cite book|title=The Quapaw Indians: A History of the Downstream People|last=Baird|first=Dr. David|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press, Norman.|year=1979|isbn= 978-0-8061-1542-9|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=handbook>{{Cite book|title=Handbook of North American Indians, Volume 13: Plains, Pt. 1 and Pt. 2|last=Sturtevant|first=William|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|year=2001|isbn=0160504007|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=handbook/><ref name=plains>{{cite book|last1=Wishart, ed.|first1=David J.|title=Encyclopedia of the Great Plains|date=2004|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=978-0-8032-4787-1|page=296|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rtRFyFO4hpEC&lpg=PA596&ots=IjBZzhBJTv&dq=Encyclopedia%20of%20the%20Great%20Plains%20Victor%20Griffin&pg=PA596#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name="Davis 2014 523">{{Cite book|title=Native America in the Twentieth Century: An Encyclopedia|last=Davis|first=Mary|publisher=Routledge|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=523}}</ref> Griffin was also a 32 degree Scottish Right [[Freemasonry|Mason]] and a member of the [[Shriners|Akdar Shrine]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Chief Victor Griffin of Quapaw Tribes Dies|work=Joplin Globe|date=11 April 1958}}</ref>
==Early life== Victor Griffin was born around 1873 in [[Indian Territory]] in what is now [[Osage County, Oklahoma]]. Griffin was orphaned at a young age, and was adopted and raised by Mary "Widow" Stafford.
Details about the early life of Griffin are scant and conflicting. Mary Stafford was born prior to the first Quapaw [[Indian removal|removal]], and died at over 100 years of age and was buried on her home allotment. Due to his upbringing with Stafford, Griffin was fluent in the [[Quapaw language]] and well versed in tribal [[oral history]]. Griffin was given the Quapaw name '''Geh-Hu-He Jinka'''.
==Translation and linguistic work== Being well educated and well spoken in both English and Quapaw, Griffin frequently served as a translator during meetings or when an elderly Quapaw tribal member needed his services, for example when drafting a will.
He was interviewed by many individuals such as news reporters and researchers. In 1940, linguist Frank T. Siebert interviewed Griffin regarding the Quapaw language; Griffin provided several Quapaw words to Siebert and stated to him "that Quapaw was closely related to Ponca and Omaha, especially to the latter... (you) should study these languages instead".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Siebert|first=Frank|date=1989|title="A note on Quapaw" International Journal of American Linguistics 55 (4)|jstor=1265244|journal=University of Chicago Press|doi=|pmid=}}</ref>
==Political career== After the death of John Quapaw, elected chief of the Quapaw Tribe, Griffin was elected chief and served from 1920 to 1957.<ref name=blue/>
During his tenure as chief, he frequently went to Washington D.C. for meetings in the interest of the Quapaw Tribe. It is noted that he met with every President of the United States that served during his time as chief. Griffin was also noted for being the first "Short-Haired Chief of the Quapaws,"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3676261/quapaw_news/|title=Miami Daily News-Record|last=Nieberding|first=Velma|date=30 April 1961|work=|access-date=11 March 2016}}</ref> because he cut off his braids.<ref name="globe">{{cite web|last1=Okeson|first1=Sarah|title=Quapaw Tribe working to pass on native language|url=http://www.joplinglobe.com/news/quapaw-tribe-working-to-pass-on-native-language/article_a8c99b16-30ec-11e5-9e57-77264e185c36.html|website=The Joplin Globe|accessdate=12 March 2016|date=22 July 2015}}</ref> He was quoted as saying "formerly our chiefs were chosen by inheritance but now we are elected".<ref name=averie/>
While serving as chief, Griffin was known for colorful displays and often was pictured in tribal regalia, which often included a full Plains eagle-feather headdress.<ref name=averie>{{Cite book|title=The Social and Economic History of the Quapaw Tribe of Indians Since 1833|last=Averie|first=Essie|publisher=Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College|year=1938|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Griffin also featured prominently in the commemorative festivities when paving was completed for [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]] in [[Quapaw, Oklahoma]] on March 24, 1933. The two halves of Route 66 met in the town of Quapaw, leading to the town being referred to in some instances as "where east meets west." Griffin laid a zinc tablet on Main Street to memorialize the event.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Route 66 Encyclopedia|last=Hinckley|first=Jim|publisher=Voyageur Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=206}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Mickey|title=Quapaw|url=http://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=QU004|website=Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture|publisher=Oklahoma Historical Society|accessdate=11 March 2016|date=2009}}</ref>
In 1956, the Quapaw Tribe, influenced by the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]],<ref name=blue/> ended their system of governance by chief. They passed a series of governing resolutions that created new form of government by an elected tribal business committee headed by a chairperson.<ref name=globe/> When this took place, Griffin no longer held his position as chief and the political authority of the Quapaw Tribe was vested in the new committee.<ref name=baird/><ref name=handbook/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quapawtribe.com/ArchiveCenter/ViewFile/Item/229|title=Quapaw Tribe of Oklahoma Governing Resolution|last=|first=|date=|website=www.quapawtribe.com|publisher=Official Quapaw Tribal Website|access-date=9 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Handbook of North American Indians, Volume 13: Plains, Pt. 1 and Pt. 2|last=Sturtevant|first=William|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|year=2001|isbn=0160504007|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title="Disintegration and Revitalization" Quapaws, Indians of North America|last=Baird|first=David|publisher=Chelsea House Publishers|year=1989|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
==Native American Church involvement== [[John Wilson (Caddo)|John Wilson]] ([[Caddo]]-[[Delaware Nation|Delaware]]), also known as Moonhead, introduced the Peyote religion to the Quapaw people living near present-day Quapaw, Oklahoma, in 1880<ref name=religion/> or the mid-1890s at the request of [[Tall Chief]].<ref name=religion/><ref name=walker>{{Cite book|title=Josephine Walker Interview, 1968|last=|first=|publisher=Oklahoma Federation of Labor Collection, M453, Box 5, Folder 2. Western History Collections, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=9–12}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.quapawtribalancestry.com/oralhistory/page6.htm|title=Quapaw Tribe Oral History|website=www.quapawtribalancestry.com|access-date=2016-03-09}}</ref> Because [[Roman Catholic]] missionaries had influenced Quapaw religion, their practice of peyotism incorporates aspects of Catholicism.<ref name="blue">{{cite book|last1=Clark|first1=Blue|title=Indian Tribes of Oklahoma: A Guide|date=2013|publisher=University of Oklahoma|location=Norman|isbn=978-0-8061-4061-2|page=n.p.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8U9fc2833xQC&lpg=PT502&dq=Victor%20Griffin%20Quapaw&pg=PT502#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name=religion/>
When he visited Quapaw, Moonhead introduced Griffin to peyotism. Griffin was in his teenage years or early twenties.<ref name="walker" /><ref name=":0" /> Moonhead instructed Griffin in this religion and authorized him to conduct Native American Church ceremonies.<ref name=walker/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drugtext.org/The-Peyote-Cult/plates.html|title=Plates by Weston La Barre|last=|first=|date=2011|website=International Substance Use Library|publisher=|access-date=11 March 2016}}</ref> Following John Wilson's death, Griffin became the Native American Church priest to the Quapaw.<ref name=blue/>
Griffin became an ardent believer in the Peyote religion and helped to spread its practice, especially among members of the [[Osage Nation|Osage]] and Quapaw tribes, but also among other tribal groups such as the [[Seneca-Cayuga Tribe of Oklahoma]].<ref name="religion" /><ref name="baird" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quapawtribalancestry.com/marymaudeangel.htm|title=Quapaw Tribe Mary Maude Angel Grandma Supernaw a Historical Legend|website=www.quapawtribalancestry.com|access-date=2016-03-09}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Peyote Religious Arts: Symbols of Faith and Belief|last=Swan|first=Daniel|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
He also was instrumental in the incorporation of the Native American Church under Oklahoma law in 1911, the incorporation of the religion specified the use of peyote as a sacrament.<ref name=baird/><ref name=handbook/><ref name=plains/><ref name="Davis 2014 523"/><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Early Osage Peyotism|last=Swan|first=Daniel|publisher=Plains Anthropologist|year=1998|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
==Death and legacy== Griffin died at his home residence near the Spring River outside of the town of [[Quapaw, Oklahoma|Quapaw]], in [[Ottawa County, Oklahoma|Ottawa County]], OK, in 1958 at the approximate age of 85.<ref name=averie/>
Griffin's image was featured on a brick sculpture between Twelfth and Military Avenue in [[Baxter Springs, Kansas]]. The sculpture depicts local history and includes a depiction of Griffin.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://onlinebanking.americanbankbaxter.com/Pages/mural.html|title=Baxter Springs News|last=Smith|first=JC|date=1999|work="Brick Sculpture depicts Baxter Springs Heritage" pg 8|access-date=11 March 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMNP9M_Baxter_springs_Relief_Sculpture_Kansas_USA|title=Baxter springs - Relief Sculpture - Kansas, USA. - Relief Art Sculptures on Waymarking.com|website=www.waymarking.com|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref>
Victor and Minnie Track Griffin's granddaughter, [[Ardina Moore]] teaches the Quapaw language today.<ref name=globe/>

revision.text:
The '''Women's Torah Project''' ('''WTP''') was an initiative to have the first [[Sefer Torah|Torah scroll]] [[Sofer|scribed]] entirely by women. The project began in 2003 and was completed in [[Seattle]] in 2010. Wendy Graff was the leader of WTP.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013165249_torah15m.html|title=Rare New Torah Made by Women Debuts Saturday in Seattle|last=Bartley|first=Nancy|date=14 October 2010|work=The Seattle Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618080917/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013165249_torah15m.html|archive-date=18 June 2012|access-date=2 June 2016|via=}}</ref> The WTP was commissioned by the Seattle-based Kadima [[Reconstructionist Judaism|Reconstructionist]] community.
== History == The Kadima Reconstructionist community of Seattle decided to purchase a Torah scroll written by women for their congregation in the early 2000s.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://forward.com/articles/133017/women-who-write-torah/|title=Women Who Write Torah|last=Strauss|first=Elissa|date=10 November 2010|work=Forward|access-date=2 June 2016|via=}}</ref> Previously, they had been borrowing scrolls.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/64329/unfurling-a-piece-of-history-womens-torah-to-embark-on-eight-day-local-tour/|title=Unfurling a Piece of History: Women's Torah to Embark on Eight-Day Local Tour|last=Silvers|first=Emma|date=16 February 2012|work=J Weekly|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> They started looking for women [[Sofer|scribes]], but had trouble finding any at first.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/59670/cjms-resident-scribe-takes-part-in-group-torah-project-in-seattle/|title=CJM's Resident Scribe Takes Part in Group Torah Project in Seattle|last=Fishkoff|first=Sue|date=21 October 2010|work=J Weekly|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> The reason there were no women scribes was because of the prohibition in [[Halakha|Jewish law]] against women writing a Torah scroll for ritual use.<ref name=":1" /> Kadima eventually found a "''[[Halakha|halachically]]'' acceptable" way to create the Torah and began to look at multiple scribes for the project.<ref name=":4" />
The scroll was commissioned in 2003.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/121108/njScribeWritesAScroll.html|title=Scribe Writes a Scroll, and Revises a Tradition|last=Ginsberg|first=Johanna|date=11 December 2008|work=New Jersey Jewish News|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> Kadima supported the training of two women scribes and the other four trained on their own.<ref name=":3" /> The scribes included Rachel Reichhardt, who was also the only officially certified scribe, Linda Coppleson, Irma Penn, Rabbi Hanna Klebansky, Julie Seltzer, and [[Aviel Barclay]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=jta>{{cite web |url= http://www.jta.org/2005/02/27/life-religion/features/female-scribe-writes-torah-scroll|title=Female Scribe Writes Torah Scroll|first=Dan|last=Pine|date=27 February 2005|accessdate=15 December 2015|work=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]}}</ref> The lead scribe (or ''[[Sofer|soferet]]'') on the project was Shoshana Gugenheim.<ref name=":1" /> Gugenheim said that "it was important to me that there would be other women scribes".<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/Torah-she-wrote|title=Torah She Wrote|last=Spiro|first=Amy|date=7 October 2012|work=The Jerusalem Post|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> The work of the scribes was checked by [[Jen Taylor Friedman]], who created a [[Book of Esther|Scroll of Esther]] and was the first woman to scribe any part of the Torah in modern times.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://jewishcurrents.org/october-15-the-womens-torah-12502|title=October 15: The Women's Torah|last=|first=|date=14 October 2012|work=Jewish Currents|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> When the pages were finished, the parchment panels were further checked and minor ''tikkunim'' (corrections) made by experts in [[New York City|New York]] and [[Jerusalem]].<ref name=":3" /> The individual sections were sewn together by a group of women.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jta.org/2010/10/15/life-religion/womens-torah-dedicated-in-seattle|title=Women's Torah Dedicated in Seattle|last=Fishkoff|first=Sue|date=15 October 2010|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref>
Special [[Klaf|parchment]] to write the Torah, made at a factory in Israel, could be purchased only by men.<ref name=":0" /> In order to purchase the parchment, Rabbi Hanna Klebansky had to pretend to be purchasing the parchment for her husband.<ref name=":0" /> The mantle for the Torah was created by Sooze Bloom deLeon Grossman, and was created out of more than 70 pieces of fabric.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vashonbeachcomber.com/news/105793563.html|title=An Island Woman Sews a Historic Mantle for a Holy Book|last=Johnson|first=Natalie|date=26 October 2010|work=Beachcomber|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> Many of the pieces of fabric were formerly pieces of clothing belonging to Jewish women that were sent to Grossman for the mantle.<ref name=":2" /> The portions of women's belongings makes up the shape of a [[pomegranate]] on the mantle.<ref name=":4" /> The Torah crown was created by Aimee Golant.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/S-F-metal-artist-crowned-Women-s-Torah-Project-3084773.php|title=S.F. Metal Artist Crowned Women's Torah Project|last=Guthmann|first=Edward|date=7 February 2012|work=SF Gate|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref>
The total cost of the project was nearly $100,000.<ref name=":0" /> The Women's Torah [[Inauguration of a Torah scroll|was dedicated]] on October 15, 2010.<ref name=":7" /> On October 16, women read from the Women's Torah for the first time during the [[Shabbat]] service.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.king5.com/news/local/Women-Create-Torah-in-Seattle--105086339.html |title=First Known Torah Written by Women to Debut in Seattle |last= |first= |date=15 October 2010 |work=KING 5 News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618035859/http://www.king5.com/news/local/Women-Create-Torah-in-Seattle--105086339.html |archive-date=June 18, 2012 |access-date=2 June 2016 |via= |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
== Jewish law and the Women's Torah == According to the [[Talmud]] (''[[Nashim|Gittin]]'' 45b), a Torah scroll written by a woman for ritual use is invalid.<ref name=forward>{{cite web |url= http://forward.com/articles/3614/a-female-scribe-e2-80-99s-trailblazing-effort/|title=A Female Scribe's Trailblazing Effort|first=Alice|last=Lowenstein|date=3 June 2005|accessdate=15 December 2015|work=[[The Forward]]}}</ref> The [[Arba'ah Turim]], however, does not prohibit women from becoming scribes.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://jwa.org/thisweek/oct/16/2010/women%E2%80%99s-torah-project|title=First Torah Commissioned to be Scribed Entirely By Women is Read in Seattle|last=|first=|date=16 October 2010|work=Jewish Women's Archive|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref> Several modern-day rabbis have presented arguments supporting the view that a woman can write a scroll for ritual use.<ref name=forward/> A Conservative Israeli Rabbi, Simcha Roth, wrote that since women may learn the Torah, "they should certainly be eligible to write a scroll".<ref name=":5" /> Linda Coppleson, who is a [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative Jew]], expresses that while the Talmud forbids women from writing Torah scrolls, it also states that "whoever is qualified should write a Torah;" and when women have "the same opportunities as men, it is fitting to remove them from forbidden categories".<ref name=":6" /> Wendy Graff, the project's leader, said that "if my daughter could read and study the Torah and yet not be allowed to create the scroll that is the basis of our faith, then we still have a long way to go".<ref name=":8" />
Members of the Women's Torah Project recognize that some Jewish communities do not see the Women's Torah as valid. Taylor Friedman says that it is important to keep women's Torah scrolls out of [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] communities.<ref name=":5" /> Torah scrolls written by women are not considered [[Kashrut|kosher]] by all Jewish communities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/10/15/2741314/an-all-women-torah-is-completed-in-seattle|title=Female Scribes Finish Writing Torah Scroll|last=Fishkoff|first=Sue|date=15 October 2010|work=JTA|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101022110146/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/10/15/2741314/an-all-women-torah-is-completed-in-seattle|archive-date=22 October 2010|access-date=3 June 2016|via=}}</ref>

In the cultures of the [[Horn of Africa]] and adjacent regions of the [[Middle East]],<ref>"found in Ethiopia, Eritrea, Djibouti, Somalia, Arabia, south and south-west Iran, Egypt and the Sudan." {{cite journal | last1 = Natvig | first1 = Richard | year = 1987 | title = Oromos, Slaves, and Zar Spirits: a Contribution to the History of the Zar Cults | url = | journal = The International Journal of African Historical Studies | volume = 20 | issue = 4| pages = 647–668 | doi=10.2307/219657| jstor = 219657 }}</ref> '''''Zār''''' ({{lang-ar|زار}}, {{lang-gez|ዛር}}) is the term for a [[demon]] or spirit assumed to [[spirit possession|possess]] individuals, mostly women, and to cause discomfort or illness. The so-called ''' ''zār'' ritual''' or ''' ''zār'' cult''' is the practice of [[exorcism|exorcising]] such spirits from the possessed individual.<ref name="EDD">R. Guiley, ''The Encyclopedia of Demons and Demonology'' (2009), [https://books.google.ch/books?id=NHosWhaeWDQC&pg=PA277 p. 277].</ref>
''Zār'' exorcism has become popular in the contemporary urban culture of [[Cairo]] and other major cities of the Islamic world as a form of women-only entertainment. ''Zār'' gatherings involve food and musical performances, and they culminate in ecstatic dancing, lasting between three and seven nights.<ref name="EDD"/> The ''[[Tanbūra (lyre)|tanbura]]'', a six-string [[lyre]] (6-stringed "bowl-lyre"<ref>Makris 2000, p. 52</ref>), is often used in the ritual.<ref name="grove">{{NewGrove2001|article=Tanbūra|last=Poché|first=Christian|vol=xxv|pages=62–63}}</ref> Other instruments include the ''[[mangour]]'', a leather belt sewn with many [[Domestic goat|goat]] [[hoof|hooves]], and various [[percussion instrument]]s.<ref name="grove" />
==History== Scholarship in the early 20th century attributed Abyssinian (Ethiopian) origin to the custom, although there were also proposals suggesting Persian or other origins. Thus, [[Leo Frobenius|Frobenius]] suggested that '' zār'' and ''bori'', a comparable cult in [[Hausa people|Hausa]] culture, were ultimately derived from a Persian source. Modarressi (1986) suggests a Persian etymology for the term.<ref>Taghi Modarressi, "The Zar Cult in South Iran," in R. Prince, ed., Trance and Possession States, Montreal, 1986, pp. 149-55.</ref>
The origin of the word is unclear; Walker (1935) suggested the name of the city of [[Zara, Iran (disambiguation)|Zara]] in northern Iran, or alternatively the Arabic root ''[[:wikt:زار#Verb|z-w-r]]'' "to visit" (for the possessing spirit "visiting" the victim). The ''[[Encyclopedia of Islam]]'' of 1934 favoured an Ethiopian origin of the word.<ref name="auto">cited after Fakhouri (1968), p. 49.</ref>
The spread beyond the Horn of Africa likely dates to the 18th or early 19th century, presumably introduced by Ethiopian slaves brought to the [[harem]]s of the Ottoman [[Egypt Eyalet]].<ref name="auto"/> Messing (1958) states that the cult was particularly well-developed in Northern Ethiopia ([[Amhara Region|Amhara]]), with its center in the town of [[Gondar]]. One late 19th-century traveler describes the Abyssinian "Sár" cultists sacrificing a hen or goat and mixing the blood with grease and butter, in the hopes of eliminating someone's sickness. The concoction was then hidden in an alley, in the belief that all who pass through the alley would take away the patient's ailment.<ref>William Cornwallis Harris, ''The Highlands of Aethiopia,'' volume 2, p. 291</ref>
Mirzai Asl (2002) suggests that the introduction to Iran likewise took place in the 19th century ([[Qajar dynasty|Qajar period]]) by Africans brought to Iran via the [[Arab slave trade]].<ref>Behnaz A. Mirzai Asl, "African Presence in Iran: Identity and its Reconstruction in the 19th and 20th Centuries," Revue française d'histoire d'Outre Mer 89, 2002, pp. 229-46.</ref> Natvig (1988) reports that the ''zār'' cult "served as a refuge for women and effeminate men" in the [[Sudan (region)|Sahel (Sudan) region]] under [[Islamization of the Sudan region|Islamic rule]].<ref name=numen>{{Citation|last=Natvig|first=Richard|title=Liminal Rites and Female Symbolism in the Egyptian Zar Possession Cult|journal=Numen|volume=35|issue=1|date=July 1988|pages=57–68|doi=10.2307/3270140|jstor=3270140}}</ref>
==Varieties == Among extant varieties of Zār cults are "''zār Sawāknī'' (the ''zār'' from the area of [[Suakin]] ["''Dalūka'', that is, ''zār Sawāknī''"<ref>Makris 2000, p. 141</ref>]) and ''zār Nyamānyam'' {cf. /NYAMe/ ('Friend'), god of the Akan} (the ''zār'' of the [[Azande]])":<ref>Makris 2000, p. 12</ref> "the Nyam-Nyam have ''zār nugāra'', with Babīnga and Nakūrma". "Babīnga and Nakūrma are recognized as Azande ancestral spirits". Nugāra (big drum) = "''nuqara'' ... of the Dega tribe ... was originally from Wau".<ref>Makris 2000, p. 64</ref> (Wau is in Equatoria province of Sudan.) "Besides the nugāra of the Azande, other zār cults mentioned were those of the Fartīt [Fartīt peoples include "the Karra, Gula, Feroge, and Surro"<ref>Makris p. 222, n. 5:15</ref>], the [[Shilluk people]], and the [[Dinka people]] and the ''dinia'' [[Nuba peoples|Nuba]] cult".<ref>Makris 2000, pp. 64-65</ref>
==Spirits== In Ethiopia, ''zār'' is used as a term for malevolent spirits or demons. At the same time, many Ethiopians believe in benevolent, protective spirits, or ''abdar''.<ref name="turner">Turner, John W. Ethiopian Orthodox Christianity: Faith and Practices. ''[http://memory.loc.gov/frd/cs/ettoc.html A Country Study: Ethiopia]''. Thomas P. Ofcansky and LaVerle Berry, eds. Washington: Library of Congress Federal Research Division, 1991.</ref>
Belief in such spirits is widespread among both Christians and Muslims.<ref name="beckwith">Beckwith, Carol, Angela Fisher, and Graham Hancock. ''African Ark''. New York: Henry N. Abrams, Inc., 1990.</ref>{{Rp|199}} As is usual in African animism, and in pre-modern folk belief in general, what would be termed mental illness in modern psychiatry is attributed to spirit possession.<ref name="kemp">Kemp, Charles. "[http://bearspace.baylor.edu/Charles_Kemp/www/ethiopian_refugees.htm Ethiopians & Eritreans.]" ''Refugee Health – Immigrant Health''. Waco, TX: Baylor University.</ref> ''Ĥēṭ'' ("thread"<ref>Makris 2000, p. 195</ref>){{huh|date=May 2016}}<!--Ĥ is a letter used to transcribe Esperanto and Chinook--> is a term of for the possessing spirits. ''Tumbura'' is another term.{{huh|date=May 2016}} Named individual ''tumbura'' include: ''Nuba, Banda, Gumuz, Sawākiniyya, Lambūnāt, Bābūrāt, Bāshawāt, Khawājāt''.<ref>Makris 2000, p. 197</ref> Depending on which spirit an individual is possessed by, they will don different costumes, such a traditional loincloth for ''Nuba'', a straw loincloth for ''Bada'', a red fez for ''Bāśawāt'', and a pith-helmet and khaki shorts for ''Ĥawājāt''.<ref>Makris 2000, p. 198–203</ref>
According to legend, there are eighty-eight "Sároch", emissaries of evil all under the service of a spirit named "Warobal Mama",<ref>William Cornwallis Harris, ''The Highlands of Aethiopia,'' volume 2, p. 269</ref> who dwells in lake Alobar in the [[Menz]] region.<ref>William Cornwallis Harris, ''The Highlands of Aethiopia,'' volume 2, p. 343</ref>
Zār beliefs are common today even among Ethiopian immigrants to North America, Europe, or Israel. For example, [[Beta Israel]] are often raised with both [[Judaism|Jewish]] and Zār beliefs, and individuals who believe they house a spirit are bound to attend to it despite other demands. However, ceremonies can be performed by [[shamans]] to persuade a spirit to leave, thus releasing the person from their duties to that spirit.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Edelstein|first1=Monika|title=Lost Tribes and Coffee Ceremonies: Zar Spirit Possession and the Ethno-Religious Identity of Ethiopian Jews in Israel|journal=Journal of Refugee Studies|date=2002|volume=15|issue=2|url=http://webhome.weizmann.ac.il/home/liorg/zar.pdf|accessdate=5 August 2015|doi=10.1093/jrs/15.2.153|pages=153–170}}</ref>
In southern Iran, ''zār'' is interpreted as a "harmful wind" assumed to cause discomfort or illness. Types of such winds include ''Maturi, Šayḵ Šangar, Dingemāru, Omagāre, Bumaryom, Pepe, Bābur, Bibi, Namrud''.<ref name="EncIr"> Maria Sabaye Moghaddam, [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/zar ZĀR], ''[[Encyclopedia Iranica]]'' (2009).</ref> The film ''The African-Baluchi Trance Dance'' is a 2012 film that depicts a variety of ''zar''-related activities in southeastern Iran.<ref>Hegland, Mary Elaine. 2017. Review essay. ''Iranian Studies'' 50.1:169-172.</ref>
